The images from Myanmar or Burma are stunning.
Many thousands of monks in maroon robes marching barefoot through the streets, now with tens of thousands of other protesters by their side.
It's the strongest challenge to the military regime in Myanmar since huge protests were crushed nearly 20 years ago.
And today, the regime threatened to crackdown on the protesters if senior Buddhist clerics don't rein them in.
Michael Green joins us to talk about what influence the United States might bring to bear.
He was the top Asia official at the National Security Council earlier in the Bush administration.
Thanks for being with us.
Thank you.
And there's news today that President Bush will be raising the issue of Myanmar in his speech at the United Nations tomorrow.
What do you expect him to say?
Well, this issue has been important to him personally and to the first lady who's actually written an op-ed that's called ""The Secretary General of the U.N."" and so forth.
I am told that he will be announcing tighter sanctions.
The U.S.
has sanctioned several times, several layers of sanctions against the regime.
There will be new efforts to plug holes in that sanctions regime - a visa ban on senior government officials, tightening financial transfers.

I think the administration is also looking at ways, though, to make sure that these sanctions don't get in the way of non-governmental organizations trying to help on the humanitarian front or with the democracy movement.
The message today from the White House, from the State Department, about these protests is that the government of Myanmar should exercise restraint.
Do you think that's a message that carries any weight with the authorities there?
Well, there are very worrisome things happening on the ground.
Apparently, visas are being cancelled or denied for travel into Burma.
The junta has sent some very stern warnings.
It may be that they are preparing to seal the borders and crack down violently.
So I think what you'll hear from the administration is a warning that they'll be held accountable for that.

The fact that the president is in New York with over 120 world leaders, that Secretary Rice is meeting on Thursday with the foreign ministers from Southeast Asia, all of those are opportunities to get those governments to speak out to and warn the junta that they need to not only make progress in restoring democracy, but they will be held accountable for how they handle these protests.
I think now is the time to send the warnings, not only from Washington, I think we need them to hear it from the region as well.
When you say that the junta would be held accountable, in what way?
How have they ever been held accountable in the past?
Well, that's a very good question.
In general, the U.S.
and some western governments have imposed sanctions, while the neighbors, China, India, Thailand and so forth, have been reluctant to do that.
But the neighbors, especially in Southeast Asia, are increasingly unhappy with the junta's unwillingness to make, you know, reasonable steps to bring stability and some inclusive political process.
We should be pushing them harder than we have been to send a warning.
They provide significant aid, China and India in particular.
China has desired a good relationship with the U.S., a good housekeeping seal of approval from Washington.
As they go into the Olympics, they want us to be saying that they are good corporate international citizen.
India, as a democracy, has been trumpeting, their democratic values and shared values with Washington.
I think we need to hold them both to account in this specific case.
And they provide significant aid, and we need them to be telling the junta that that would be in peril if the junta really does crack down in the way that they may be poised to now do.
Do you see this being at a flashpoint?
I think it's at a real turning point.
There haven't been protests like these in two decades.
And when we're talking about Buddhist monks - this is a region and a country that's primarily Buddhist, for the government to crackdown on them, really would provoke outrage in the region.
Michael Green, thanks very much.
Thank you.
Michael Green, formerly the top Asia official at the National Security Council.
He's now associate professor at Georgetown University and a senior adviser at the Center for Strategic and International Studies here in Washington, D.C.

In a room off of his kitchen, 77-year-old Marty Halperin has set up his version of heaven: a wall of audio equipment, some of it new, some of it really old.
I'm going to play a disc here to show you.
It's dated 1947.
(Soundbite of recording)
...""Jack Benny Program"" presented by Lucky Strike, quality of product is essential to continuing success.
Halperin's eyes light up as the record pops and crackles.
(Soundbite of music)
I can see it because I used to work at NBC and was a page on their show.
His love of radio started as a young child growing up in Michigan.
I moved around a lot.
And each time you move, it's sort of traumatic.
You lose your friends.
But when I'd get to a new town, I'd turn on the radio, and there were my friends.
That early escapism led to a career as a radio engineer in Los Angeles.
Halperin loved radio so much that in his spare time, he joined a fraternal group of radio fans known as the Pacific Pioneer Broadcasters.
As formats changed, radio stations were tossing out the original recordings of shows like ""Dragnet"" and ""Chandu the Magician,"" which didn't sit right with Halperin.
At a board meeting, I made the mistake of saying, `Why don't we ask our members to save their material?
And they said, `That's a great idea.
It's yours.
You're now director of acquisitions.'
Thankfully for the broadcasters, the vice president of a Hollywood bank was a big fan of radio.
He offered them free space in the facility's basement, coincidentally, the same spot where the NBC radio studios had once been.
A perfect fit, right?
Well, it was until late last year.
What has happened to us is a nightmare, and it's a catastrophe.
Sometime in the early morning of December 13th, an underground electrical transformer caught fire, spewing toxic smoke throughout the bank and its basement.
The good news is that the records can be cleaned off.
The bad news is that it'll cost over $100,000.
The amount of money involved is just unbelievable, and we don't have it.
Making things worse, Halperin and his buddies can't even look at their beloved recordings until the cleaning has happened.
The toxins are that dangerous.
The building's current owner, Washington Mutual, has been helpful in the process but has stopped short of paying the hefty cleaning fees.

Trapped in the basement are things like Bing Crosby's personal microphone and lots of odd tidbits of sound like this recording of Clark Gable singing an impromptu version of ""Happy Birthday"" to his wife Carol Lombard.
(Soundbite of ""Happy Birthday"" by Clark Gable)
(Singing) Happy birthday to you.
Happy birthday to you.
Happy birthday, dear Ma.
Happy birthday to you.
There's also a copy of the original 1938 broadcast of ""War of the Worlds.
(Soundbite of ""War of the Worlds"")
The Columbia Broadcasting System and its affiliated stations present Orson Welles and the Mercury Theater on the Air in ""The War of the Worlds"" by H.G.
Wells.
People who turned into the show late, even by a minute, missed the opening, and they thought it was real.
(Soundbite of ""War of the Worlds"")
With World War II just around the corner, the broadcast set off a national pandemonium.
Halperin's friend in Los Angeles had just gotten off his shift at the radio station.
The manager is coming out the door carrying two suitcases.
And he said, `Where are you going?
He said, `Oh, I'm leaving.
The martians are here.'
Halperin and his friends are hoping for the best, but as of now, their archives are in limbo.
If they want to hear their treasured recordings, they'll have to rely on their imaginations.
Fortunately, that's something that comes naturally.
